DOCNAME: CASE OF ROMUALD KOZLOWSKI v. POLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He is a retired police officer who had formerly been employed in ORG ( NORP GPE ) . In DATE the applicant had been dismissed from service for a disciplinary offence . He was rehired by the Police in DATE . He retired in DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action against ORG for compensation on the grounds that in DATE he had been unlawfully dismissed from his post at ORG and banned from working there until DATE . In addition the applicant claimed that he had not been hired by the new police services immediately after the change of the political regime , as he should have been , but only in DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant sought compensation , which comprised damages for lost earnings from DATE to DATE , for lost earnings and benefits from DATE , and for alleged moral suffering due to the loss of employment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ( PERSON ) rejected the claim on the ground that the civil court did not have jurisdiction over a dispute arising out of an employment relationship between a civil servant and the ORG ( niedopuszczalność drogi sądowej ) .
CARDINAL . As a result of an interlocutory appeal by the applicant , on an unspecified date the ORG ( ORG ) quashed that decision and remitted the case to the Poznań Regional Court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG rejected the claim on the ground of lack of jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of Appeal quashed that decision and remitted the case indicating that the applicant 's claim was of a civil character as it had arisen out of relations between a civil servant and the ORG which were of an administrative and legal character rather than from a bond of special trust and loyalty between the CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the applicant 's claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of Appeal quashed the first - instance judgment in the part concerning the claim for compensation for lost earnings from DATE and remitted the case in this part to the lower court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the case . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . It appears that on DATE the appellate court issued an order to hold a hearing on DATE .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG of Appeal delivered a judgment varying the judgment of ORG of DATE and ordering that the respondent pay the applicant a certain amount of compensation for lost earnings and benefits from DATE .
A cassation appeal in the case was inadmissible in law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint about the unreasonable length of proceedings for compensation for lost earnings and benefits from DATE under LAW of DATE on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time ( LOC o skardze na naruszenie prawa strony do rozpoznania sprawy w postępowaniu sądowym bez nieuzasadnionej zwłoki ) ( “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) . The applicant submitted that his civil case had been pending for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings under LAW on the ground that the civil proceedings which were the subject of the complaint had meanwhile terminated .

CARDINAL . The court observed that the main purpose of the complaint about the unreasonable length of proceedings was to accelerate the proceedings before a trial court . In circumstances where the proceedings which were the subject of the complaint had already terminated it was no longer necessary for the court to examine the complaint under LAW . ORG noted that the applicant had admittedly lodged his complaint under LAW while the civil proceedings in question were still pending . Nevertheless , the appellate hearing , which turned out to be final , had been scheduled prior to the applicant 's complaint . That , in ORG opinion , constituted a decisive argument for holding that the proceedings under LAW ought to be discontinued without a ruling on the merits .

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice concerning remedies for the excessive length of judicial proceedings , in particular the applicable provisions of LAW , are stated in the ORG 's decisions in cases of ORG v.
